title.narrative: Yes I do Malawi incl COVID-19 prevention

description.narrative: Deep-rooted norms and expectations of girls and boys makes families and communities feel the need to control the sexuality of girls by marrying them off. Gender inequality is putting girls in a subordinate position with regard to boys and men in (sexual) relationships. For example, girls cannot refuse to have unprotected sex and this is resulting in a high level of teenage pregnancies. Girls and boys lack a voice, as well as the support to break through these norms and practices. The means and structures available for adolescents to organise themselves and claim their rights are limited and they have little access to adolescent-friendly and good quality SRHR information and services. There are close links between EM and teenage pregnancies and girls’ lack of education. Indeed, girls’ access to education is very restricted, which makes it difficult for them to find jobs later. It also hampers their economic independence. Legislation to outlaw EM is either inadequate or is being poorly implemented.

During the inception phase (January – June 2016) country-specific plans will be developed, target groups and final beneficiaries identified and activities that are based on the overall intervention strategies will be designed.

EM and teenage pregnancies mutually reinforce one another. Social and gender norms perpetuating EM are deeply embedded in communities and this situation can only be changed if community leaders and most of the people, including boys and men, support the change. Key persons in the communities, including boys and men, will be turned into allies in the process of changing these norms, thereby helping to address the problem of EM and teenage pregnancies. A general lack of information about SRHR and poor quality and access to the relevant services are perpetuating the above-mentioned problems. Adolescent boys and girls are being informed about SRHR and given a voice to claim these rights. Girls are being given more control over their lives. This is being achieved by changing these norms and people’s behaviour, strengthening networks and structures for social mobilisation and embedding these in communities, and by involving the government and the private sector in improving SRHR and services. All these will help to reduce EM and teenage pregnancies.
Final beneficiaries are girls between the age of 12 – 24 years, married and unmarried.

SUMMARY Millions of adolescent girls all over the world are facing a limited future because of early marriage (EM) and teenage pregnancies. With this project, by changing the attitude of community members and other key persons and informing adolescent girls and boys, adolescents will be empowered to stand up for their sexual reproductive health and rights (SRHR). Through education and economic empowerment, supported by the relevant legislation and policies, the project will give adolescents alternatives beyond EM and teenage pregnancies. The project will be implemented between 2016 and 2020 by Plan International Nederland, together with partners Amref, Rutgers, Choice, KIT and the Netherlands’ Embassy (located in in Harare, Zimbabwe). Next to Malawi, similar projects under the same framework will be carried out in Ethiopia, Kenya, Zambia, Mozambique, Indonesia and Pakistan.

This programme is a follow up of the Plan regional EM programme (18+) in Malawi, Zambia and Mozambique, in which adolescents are being trained as agents of change to make their voice heard in claiming their SRH rights. The programme is being implemented by the Yes I Do alliance in which each partner is adding value by implementing part of one or more of the intervention strategies.
This will be worked out per country.

policy-marker.narrative: Protection against violence (including gender based violence)

title.narrative: Policies and legislations are being aligned with the with rights of children and youth and gender equality
# of new or adjusted national and local law and policies prohibiting CM and FGM and C (disaggregated by CM and FGM and C and by policies laws national level local level)

description.narrative: The data was collected through Key informant interviews with NGO staff and policy makers.

comment.narrative: # of new or adjusted national and local law and policies prohibiting CM and FGM and C (disaggregated by CM and FGM and C and by policies laws national level local level)

At national level, the constitution was changed in 2017, defining children to be those under 18 years and child marriage to be illegal. Yes I Do contributed to this, as well as to the Ending Child Marriage Strategy at national level. At the TA Liwonde level, a bylaw has been established through the efforts of Yes I Do. The bylaw is implemented to different extent in different areas in TA Liwonde. The bylaw says that child marriage should be dissolved and people involved will be fined. In addition, it stipulates issues around prevention of teenage pregnancy, school drop-out and sexual violance. At the district council level, it will be recognized (currently in progress), which is unique in Malawi. After this, the bylaw will cover not only TA Liwonde, but the whoel of Machinga district.

title.narrative: Children, youth or adults have skills to make changes to their lives
% boys aged 15-24 who disagree with the statement: "It is not appropriate for a girl to propose to use a condom" (TA Liwonde)

description.narrative: A community-based cluster sample survey was administered at the household level among young girls and boys aged 15-24 in the intervention area (TA Liwonde). The survey included question about child marriage. We obtained a sample size of 1600 using a standard formula- taking into account possible “design effects” because of the clustered sampling- we multiplied the required sample by 1.5 and had a ratio of 75% female respondents and 25% male respondents. A total of 1596 questionnaires were administered- very slightly below the planned target. No contributing partners.

comment.narrative: % boys aged 15-24 who disagree with the statement: "It is not appropriate for a girl to propose to use a condom" (TA Liwonde)

title.narrative: Number of youth who are economically active
Children, youth or adults act to advance rights of children and youth
(Qualitative) changes observed relative to baseline in active engagement of men and boys in strategies reducing FGM and C and CM and TP (disaggregated by CM FGM and C and TP)

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews with boys aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years and focus group discussions with groups of boys aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years.

comment.narrative: (Qualitative) changes observed relative to baseline in active engagement of men and boys in strategies reducing FGM and C and CM and TP (disaggregated by CM FGM and C and TP)

Active engagement of men and boys in strategies reducing teenage pregnancy and child marriage is there, however, there are no specific movements established, man and boys participate in the general activities taking place at community level.

title.narrative: Communities take charge of their own development processes
(Qualitative) changes observed relative to baseline in attitudes and actions of gate keepers to prevent CM and TP (more or less supportive compared to baseline)

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews gatekeepers (parents or caregivers grandmothers or elderly women and and or religious and traditional leaders and and or teachers and and or health and social workers and and or CBO and youth organization staff). In the interviews a question was included on the attitudes and actions re. CM and TP.

comment.narrative: (Qualitative) changes observed relative to baseline in attitudes and actions of gate keepers to prevent CM and TP (more or less supportive compared to baseline)
Most gatekeepers have a positive attitude towards prevention of teenage pregnancy and child marriage, and some gatekeepers are involved in actively preventing teenage pregnancy and child marriage.

title.narrative: Service providers are capable to deliver services that are sensitive to rights of children and youth and gender equality (C2)
(Qualitative) changes observed relative to baseline in girls indicating safety in and out of school is a problem

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews with girls aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years and focus group discussions with groups of girls aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years.

comment.narrative: (Qualitative) changes observed relative to baseline in girls indicating safety in and out of school is a problem
Most girls indicate schools to be safe, but some girls report teachers to be involved in sexual intercourse with girls, leading to teenage pregnancy.

title.narrative: Children, youth or adults decide about their own future
(Qualitative) changes observed relative to baseline in perceived autonomy of girls between 15-24 years old

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews with girls aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years and focus group discussions with groups of girls aged between 15-19 and 20-24 years.

comment.narrative: (Qualitative) changes observed relative to baseline in perceived autonomy of girls between 15-24 years old

Most girls between 15-24 years old report to have autonomy in dating/ choosing a partner, however, they still have a limited voice in proposing condom use and when fallen pregnant, girls often do not have a choice: they are often send to the (family) of the impregnator to be taken care of.

title.narrative: Policy makers know the rights of children and youth and are willing to act accordingly
(Qualitative) changes observed relative to baseline in policy makers actively and openly supporting gender equality and girls rights

description.narrative: The data was collected through Key informant interviews with NGO staff and policy makers.

comment.narrative: (Qualitative) changes observed relative to baseline in policy makers actively and openly supporting gender equality and girls rights
Some policy makers are actively /openly supporting gender equality and girls rights.

title.narrative: Community knowledge and attitudes enable children, youth or adults to claim their rights
(qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in knowledge of gate keepers about harms of CM and TP

description.narrative: Semi-structured in-depth interviews gatekeepers (parents or caregivers grandmothers or elderly women and and or religious and traditional leaders and and or teachers and and or health and social workers and and or CBO and youth organization staff). In the interviews a question was included on the knowledge about harms of CM and TP

comment.narrative: (qualitative) Changes observed relative to baseline in knowledge of gate keepers about harms of CM and TP
The majority of the gatekeepers have knowledge about the harms of teenage pregnancy and child marriage.
